ABSTRACT

Lychnophora pinaster Mart. (Asteraceae)
is endemic to the Brazilian Cerrado. It is distributed along the altitudinal gradient of the mountainous ranges of the state of Minas Gerais . This study aimed to evaluate the influence of altitude on the genetic diversity of
L. pinaster
populations and the effects of altitude and climatic factors on essential oil chemical composition. Essential oils from
L. pinaster
populations from the north (North 01, North 02, and
North 03, 700
–859 m) and the Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MhBH 01 and MrBH 02, 1366–1498 m ) were analyzed. SNP markers from
L. pinaster
in these regions and Campos das Vertentes (CV 01, CV 02, and CV 03, 1055–1292 m ) were also analyzed. The main compounds in essential oils were 14-hydroxy-α- humulene (North 01 and North 03), cedr-8(15)-en-9-α- ol (North 02), 14-acetoxy-α- humulene (MrBH 01), and 4-oxo-15-noreudesman-11-ene (MrBH 02). Hierarchical cluster and heatmap analyses showed that the North and MrBH populations included five different groups, indicating the chemical composition of essential oils is distinct in each population. Furthermore, principal component analysis showed that higher altitudes ( 1366 m and 1498 m ) in the MrBH influence the chemical composition of essential oils, and climatic factors determine the chemical composition in North region. The genetic diversity showed that most alleles are in Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium and imply high genetic variation and genetic polymorphisms between populations. Furthermore, the results of Mantel tests (R = 0.3861517; p = 0.04709529; R = 0.9423121; p = 0.02739726) also showed that higher altitude ( > 1360 m ) shapes the genetic diversity at the MrBH. The genetic structure showed that higher altitudes ( > 1360 m ) contribute to the structure of the MrBH populations, but not to North and CV populations. Therefore, the altitudinal ranges of Minas Gerais mountainous ranges determine the higher genetic and chemical diversity of
L. pinaster
populations.

sec.title: 2.1. Yield and characterization of essential oils
sec.p:
The yield of essential oils of
five
L.
pinaster populations varied from 0.05% to 0.18% ( Table 1 ), with the highest concentrations found in the North 02 population (0.18 ± 0.11). The Kendall ranking correlation analysis showed a low correlation between yield and altitude (R =

0.026, p = 0.69); hence, the altitude did not influence the production of essential oils of
L. pinaster
. Furthermore, the yield presented inter-population variation ( Table 1 ), consistent with previous reports (
).

The essential oils of
five
L.
pinaster populations were characterized by a complex mixture mainly composed of monoterpenes (3.6–20.0%) and sesquiterpenes (3.1–74.7%, Table 1 ). In total, 46 compounds were identified, accounting for 60.5–91.0% of the constituents of essential oils. Based on linear retention indexes and mass spectra of unidentified compounds, it could be inferred that these compounds are sesquiterpenes. However, the low abundance of these compounds did not allow their isolation, and the 1 H and 13 C NMR auxiliary techniques were used for their identification, especially for essential oils of the MrBH02 population.

Essential oils of
L. pinaster
populations contained a high abundance of oxygenated sesquiterpenes (38.5–74.7%). The main constituents were 14-hydroxy-α- humulene (North 01 and North 03 populations), cedr-8 (15)-en-9-α- ol (North 02 population), 14-acetoxy-α- humulene (MrBH 01), and 4-oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene for the MrBH 02 population ( Table 1 ).

Although the North 02 and North 03 populations were close ( 8 km apart, Table S1 , Fig. 1 ), the major constituents were divergent. The same pattern was observed for the MrBH 01 and MrBH 02 populations found 23 km apart.

The cluster analysis (HCA) showed that the North and MrBH populations of
L. pinaster
were chemically distinct, generating five groups ( Fig. 2 ). Furthermore, the heatmap ( Fig. 3 ) generated as a function of the correlation coefficients of the substances from the
L. pinaster
populations shows that each population contained a group of highly correlated compounds not found in the others. The North 01 population was strongly correlated with 13 compounds, especially α- copaen-11-ol, spathulenol, and mirtenal, and in the North 02 population, these compounds were mainly cis -caryophyllene, caryophyllene oxide, cedr-8(15)- en-9-α- ol, 14-hydroxy-( Z )-caryophyllene, and γ- curcumen-15- al. The North 03 population strongly correlated with 14 compounds; it was the only population containing epi -longipinanol, sesquiterpenes 2 and 3, and dehydroxy-( E )-linalool oxide.

The MrBH 01 population strongly correlated with 19 substances, including geranyl acetate, viridiflorol, tridecanal, and (2 E )-tridecenol acetate, detected only in this population. The MrBH 02 population contained 18 compounds, of which sabinene, o -cymene, α- thujene, terpinene, and α- terpineol were not detected in other populations.

sec.title: 2.1.1. Climatic factors and altitude
sec.p: Results of PCA ( Fig. 4 and Tables S2 and S 3 ) demonstrate the

Our results show that the different regions of
L. pinaster
occurrence and mountain ranges act as natural geographic barriers for the populations, contributing to isolation and genetic population differentiation, and these factors combined with the environment, including altitude and climate, shape the plant metabolism, resulting in the production of essential oils with different chemical compositions. influence of environmental variables ( Table S3 ) on the chemical composition of essential oils. The chemical composition of essential oils diverged between the MrBH and North populations. Altitude influenced the chemical composition of the MrBH populations ( 1366 m and 1498 m ), while climatic variables influenced the North populations ( 700 m – 860 m ). In addition to altitude, the MrBH 01 population was also influenced by daily temperature variation and the MrBH 02 population by rainfall. The MrBH 01 population differed by high relative proportions of β- elemene, cumacrene, tridecanal, viridiflorol, geranyl acetate, and 14-acetoxy-α- humulene. The MrBH 02 population had a high relative proportion of terpinolene, α- thujene, β- copaen-4α- ol, undecanal, α- terpineol, terpinene, limonene, sabinene, and o -cymene ( Table S2 ).

sec.title: 2.2. Effects of altitude on the genetic variation based on SNP markers
sec.p:
High mountain range altitudes alter the genetic diversity of
L. pinaster
, showing different genetic pools for the sampled populations, implying that altitudes determine the genetic diversity of this species. GBS libraries retained a total of 1,173,904 loci during data processing (demultiplexing and quality of reads). After filtering data, a total of 29,731 loci containing high-quality SNP markers with 91.00 bp were found (S.D. ± 0.02, gstacks ), likely considered an excellent loci number to establish genetic diversity.

Medicago citrina (Font Quer) Greuter
, endemic to the western Mediterranean, presents a strong population structure and fragmentation expressed by an overall FST value of 0.386 and high inbreeding values (
). A similar pattern was found for
L. pinaster
populations. The geographical distance between populations was 8–571 km , indicating that mountainous ranges and altitudinal ranges isolate
L. pinaster

Results of the Mantel test performed between genetic matrixes (FST) and geographic distances ( Table S1 ) between populations demonstrated a high correlation value (R = 0.8036307, p = 0.0036). PCA performed with neutral and positive sets of SNPs selected by the BayeScan method ( Fig. S1 ) and by the PCAdapt method ( Fig. S2 ) also show that isolation by distance of
L. pinaster
populations contributes to the genetic diversity of the species. Admixture analyses ( Fig. 5 ) showed that regions contain distinct genetic pools, and results of the population structure also corroborate fixation index values (FST, Fig. 4 ). Mountain ranges in Minas Gerais (
) contribute to the spatial segregation of
L. pinaster ,
promoting isolation by distance of the species. Isolation by distance promotes spatial allelic segregation and alters the presence of alleles among populations (
), enhancing the inter-population genetic diversity. Therefore, mountain ranges geographically isolate
L. pinaster
located in the North and MrBH regions, increasing the inter-population diversity of this species.

Results show that the genetic diversity of
L. pinaster
populations corroborates the variation in essential oil chemical compositions. Furthermore, studies of
L. ericoides
indicate high chemical plasticity for this species regarding the location of each population and local environmental events (
), showing that endemic species suffer intense selection pressures due to geography and local climate, as observed for
L. pinaster
.

sec.title: 3. Conclusion
sec.p:
The present study showed that natural
L. pinaster
populations have high chemical and genetic inter-population diversity according to the altitudinal variation ( 700 m – 1498 m ). The chemical compositions of essential oils are distinct with differential sesquiterpene production, e. g., major compounds 14-hydroxy-α- humulene (North 01 and North 03), cedr-8(15)-en-9-α- ol (North 02), 14-acetoxy-α- humulene (MrBH 01), and 4-oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene (MrBH 02). Furthermore, climatic factors influence the chemical composition of
L. pinaster
populations from lower ( 700 m , 819 m , 859 m ) and higher ( 1366 m , 1498 m ) altitudes influence the chemical composition in populations located in the Metropolitan region of Belo Horizonte (MrBH 01, MrBH 02). We highlight that higher altitudes ( > 1360 m ) contribute to the population structure of the MrBH populations, but not to those of North (North 01, North 02, and North 03) or Campos das Vertentes (CV 01, CV 02, and CV 03) populations. Higher altitude also shaped the genetic diversity at MrBH by establishing a differential allele selection between populations.

sec.title: 4.2. Essential oil extraction
sec.p: After manual separation of fresh leaves from branches, essential oils were extracted by hydrodistillation in a Clevenger apparatus for 2 h after performing pre-tests to optimize the extraction time. The yield of essential oils was calculated on a dry basis. For each sample, three portions of fresh leaves ( 1 g /portion) were taken at the time of extraction and dried in a forced-air oven at 40 ◦ C to constant weight to calculate leaf moisture. Essential oils were kept in a freezer at 20 ◦ C until further analysis.

sec.title: 4.3. GC-FID and GC-MS analyses
sec.p: Quantitative analysis was performed using GC-FID (GC-2010/AOC-20i, Shimadzu Corporation, Kyoto , Japan ), and conditions were the same as for the GC-MS method. Area normalization was used to determine the percentage of essential oil components without using correction factors. The essential oils of the 82 sampled individuals were analyzed.

sec.title: 4.4.1. Isolation
sec.p: A sample of the essential oil of the MrBH 02 population was subjected to preparative TLC. Essential oil ( 60 mg ) was diluted with ethyl acetate (Merck, chromatographic grade), applied to a 60 F 254 silica chromatoplate (20 x 20, Merck) and eluted with a mixture of chloroform and ethyl acetate (95:5) three times. The substance was extracted from silica using methanol and dichloromethane (PA Merck). The solvent mixture was eliminated by a rotary evaporator and yielded compound 4- oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene ( 25 mg ).

sec.title: 4.4.2. 1 H and 13 C NMR analyses
sec.p: Nuclear magnetic resonance ( 1 H and 13 C NMR), heteronuclear single quantum correlation (HSQC), and heteronuclear multiple bond correlation (HMBC) were used to identify 4-oxo-15-nor-eudesman-11-ene. 1 D and 2 D NMR spectra were acquired on Brucker Inova 500 and Brucker Fourier 300 spectrometers, respectively, using CDCl 3 as a solvent, with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as the internal standard.
